title.narrative: OUTPUT 4.2. SUPPLY OF Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) SERVICES

description.narrative: By end 2021, schools, health and CNA centres and villages in the neglected zones within the 10 targeted provinces, as well as those facing endemic diseases (cholera, Guinea worm, etc) and severe malnutrition have quality and equitable drinking water supply systems and sanitation structures, which contributes to Hygiene, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Sanitation, Wash In Schools And Ecd Centres, Wash â€“ General, Water Supply, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 4: By the end of 2022, women and children in the 11 target regions, especially the most vulnerable, make greater and sustainable use of safe drinking water and sanitation services and adopt good hygiene practices to prevent diseases.

participating-org.narrative: DIRECTION DE LA NUTRITION ET DE LA TECHNOLOGIE ALIMENTAIRE

sector.narrative: Overall WASH – systems strengthening (e.g. sector-wide coordination, enabling environment and financing advocacy)

description.narrative: Water supply and Sanitation policy, planning and administration

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By end 2021, schools, health and CNA centres and villages in the neglected zones within the 10 targeted provinces, as well asthose facing endemic diseases (cholera, Guinea worm, etc) and severe malnutrition have quality and equitable drinking water supplysystems and sanitation structures

description.narrative: In 2021,;26,894;children in 57;schools against a target of 128 (44.5% annual achievement), including;8,646;girls;and;18,248 boys,;were given access to separate latrines for;boys and girls;as well as hygiene services.;;WASH management committees were;established;in these schools, and members (teachers and;pupils) were trained;in;operation and maintenance of;school WASH services.;; 8,749 additional people (;4,549 women and 4,200 men) accessed safe drinking water through the construction of four manual pump boreholes, which ;serve four community schools with 1,601 pupils.; 6,206 girls in 301 schools received MHM kits.;;; | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:23/01/2022
